titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I sent Waldstein this morning over the Bridge to hire a Droshky to be kept by the day untill we shall have occasion to send for Mrs. Reinike— At the same time I sent to Mr Gourieff the Minister of the finances requesting to see him this day; for which he appointed one O’Clock afternoon— I found Mr Labouchere with him, but he went immediately away— I spoke to Mr Gourieff concerning the ship Fox of New-York, and gave him the Document which I had received from New-York respecting it— I mentioned also the cases of the John Adams, from Savannah, which had been long waiting for admission, on account of an alteration or erasure in the register; and that of the Alexander, Captain Davis, a vessel of Mr Gray’s, from Algiers; delayed because he had no certificate of Origin from the Magistrates of the Place— Both these vessels Mr Gourieff told me were admitted— The law he said, had provided an exception respecting the Certificates of Origin, for vessels coming from the Asiatic Ports, and it was well known the Barbary States would not comply with these European regulations— Mr. Gourieff added that he made it a principle to give every facility to the admission of American vessels, and intimated that he did not much care where the vessel came from, if it came to export the Russian Productions— He gave me the papers of a vessel, from New-York, which was taken into an English Port, last Winter, and came from thence in the Spring; requesting me to look over them, and inform him whether I had any knowledge of the vessel, or considered the Captain’s protest as correct— I then went and called upon Mr: Harris; and gave him the letter to Mr: Hazard— I also gave him a letter from several Sailors at Cronstadt, complaining against their Captain; with a request that he would make enquiry concerning the facts— Mr: Harris read me part of a letter from Mr: Daschkoff to him—in which Daschkoff insinuates that Mr: Jefferson is not in harmony with Mr: Madison, and conveys the idea, that Jefferson is intriguing to come in again as President at the next Election— I called upon the Chevalier Bezerra, and Mr Navarro, neither of whom was at home— On returning to my house I found that the papers Mr: Gourieff had given me were those of the Matilda Captain Ashley, arrived at Riga; concerning which the Supercargo had written to me more than a month since, and about which I had then spoken to Mr: Gourieff— I thought the business had then been settled.— I immediately wrote him a Note, and sent it to him with the papers back, requesting the vessel might be admitted without further delay— Madame Bezerra visited our Ladies this afternoon. She goes to the Peterhoff fête, for which we received the notice and invitation from the Master of Ceremonies this day. Mrs: Adams cannot go, but Catherine engaged to go, and accompany Madam Bezerra— I walked to Count Strogonoff’s garden this Evening and heard the music of the military Band— I met and walked with Mr and Madam Schenbom— He is now since Count Stedingk’s departure the Swedish Chargé des Affaires. Mr Harris and Captain Bainbridge were here at tea, but were gone before I returned home.

2. I was free from interruption the whole of this day, and employed the morning suitably in writing— I received several letters; among which one from Mr: Russell at Paris which gives me great uneasiness; and requires certain delicate explanations— I walked after dinner to the island of Jalagin, and over Count Orloff’s Gardens which are in it— I believe this was the first day since we resided on the island that has pass’d without bringing visitors.— The Peterhoff party is for to-morrow— Catherine concluded not to go.

3. Peterhoff Fête. At eleven this morning I went into my Carriage and at a quarter before two alighted at Peterhoff at the small building opposite the palace where the foreign Ministers are received on this occasion— The distance from my house is 35 Versts or 25 Miles— I went with four horses in front, and without stopping once on the road— I was alone— Mr: Smith and Mr Gray having gone in another Chariot, with six horses. I took with me the Message to Congress at the Commencement of the last Winter’s Session, and read part of the Documents—that is the whole of Mr. Pinkney’s Correspondence— The road was crowded with Carriages of all kinds from the City gate to the Palace at Peterhoff— The invitation to the Corps Diplomatique was to a masked Ball, supper, fire-works, illumination &c— They were requested to alight and to dine at the Pavillon, destined to receive them— On arriving there I found one of the Aids of the Master of Ceremonies, and one of the running footmen of the Court who shewed me to a chamber where I could dress— I went immediately to the Apartment of Mr: & Madam Bezerra, and gave her the Card from Catherine, excusing herself for not going— They were to be presented to the Empress Mother and the Grand Duchesses. I then walked about an hour round the Garden— The principal water-works were playing, but as they form only one of the various exhibitions of this day, I did not see them so well, as at the visit we made to this palace the 24th: of last September.— The preparations for the illumination of the Evening were all made excepting the placing of the lamps.— They were erected scaffoldings of Planks in various forms, with rows of wire stuck on them in lines adapted to the figures to be represented, each wire stuck into the plank and rounded into a circle distant about six inches from the plank— The lamps were glass tumblers filled with tallow: a wick passing through the centre and the wick and surface of the tallow, brushed over with spirits of turpentine. Each of the wire circles was to hold one of these tumblers. On the gulph, about a quarter of a mile distant from the shore there were seventeen imperial Yachts, under full sail and dress’d out in a full suit of Colours— I saw Claud Gabriel, and Nelson in the Garden— Nelson appeared to be unwell— I returned to the Lodge where I now found Mr Smith and Mr Gray— We dress’d for dinner— M. de Maisonneuve the Master of Ceremonies came into the parlour where we were assembled, with Mr: and Madam Bezerra, whom he presented to Count Lauriston, inviting him to lead her into dinner— A Portuguese Minister’s Lady escorted by the French Ambassador, was in the present state of the world a singular curiosity, and excited a smile throughout the Company. The dinner ought regularly to have been presided by Count Romanzoff, but on account of his brothers death he did not attend on this occasion. Mr: Weydemeyer a member of the Council attached to the department of foreign Affairs, and M. de Maisonneuve the Master of the Ceremonies, presided and did the honours of the table. The dinner was excellent, and the fruits of all climates in profusion— Cherries, Strawberries, raspberries. Apricots, plums, peaches, Oranges, grapes and pine-apples, were served in abundance— The members of the Corps Diplomatique present were about twenty-five— After dinner we rode round the gardens, in Carriages provided by the Court— They are called Lines, and resemble a double Sopha with a seat on each side for four persons— They were on four wheels and tackled with two horses— We rode about an hour; returned to the Lodge, and lounged or played away the time untill eight O’Clock— We then went in Dominos and Venitians to the Palace, on the same Lines; and assembled in the central chamber painted all over the wainscoting with female portraits. There were already the nobility of both sexes who attend the Court; and within a quarter of an hour the imperial family appeared— The Emperor, and Grand Duke Constantine first pass’d through the chamber to the dancing Hall; and about five minutes afterwards the Empress & Empress Mother; followed by the Grand Duchesses Catherine and Ann—the Grand Dukes Nicholas and Michael, and the Princess Amelia of Baden; and the Duke and two Princes of Oldenburg— The Court and Diplomatic Corps followed them into the Ball Room, which was excessively crowded with people of all Classes and descriptions.— The Imperial family and Court Nobility walked a number of Polish dances; there was no room for any others— The Empress with her Sisters took Seats at the head of the Hall— The Empress Mother played at piquet, in an adjoining chamber— She played with the principal nobility and with the French Ambassador. Both Empresses spoke to most of the foreign Ministers— They asked me the same questions; whether my wife was there? why she was not there?— where we now resided? whether we had a comfortable house? and whether Mrs Adams would be conveniently situated for her confinement— Between 9 and 10 O’Clock the illumination commenced— Count Litta said that the whole garden was lighted up in ten minutes—there were three hundred thousand lamps, and sixteen hundred persons employed to light them.— Just after ten, the Emperor pass’d back in to the Hall of Portraits, and upon the Balcony fronting the back-garden— The fire-works were then played off— They were not upon the whole equal to those of 26. October last—they were over in a quarter of an hour— We then pass’d through several of the Halls, to a very long gallery over which was a sort of canvass roof, and in which was a long table on which the Supper was served— There were about three hundred persons sat down to this table— Among whom were the Court Circle and the foreign Ministers— The Supper was equally excellent, and the fruit as plentiful and as various as at the dinner— It was over in about an hour— Miss Gourieff told me that if I returned home this Night, I should find the Bridges raised, but I thought she was joking.— After Supper we went down, and rode round again for an hour and a half upon the lines— Madam Bezerra, though the only lady of the Corps, and an entire Stranger, presented this day for the first time at the Court, went through the whole with perfect propriety,
and without embarrassment— About a quarter past one we returned to the Lodge—to separate, and retire for the Night; or undress to return home— The day-light was already beginning to return, and many of the lamps were already extinct.— Mr Jones who returned the last Evening from Moscow without having been able to reach Makarieff, came spontaneously to the Lodge about 7. in the Evening, and from that time introduced himself every where, as in the suite of the Corps Diplomatique— General Pardo was the only foreign Minister absent— Navarro and Luxbourg were not there; but they have taken leave at Court. Baron’s d’Arnim, Gremp and Marechal were also absent. General Betancourt received the red ribband of the Order of St: Alexander Nefsky, while there, at the Ball— A curious part of the show was the Circassian deputies in their National dresses, when presented to and spoken to by the Empress.

4. At half past one in the morning, I entered my Carriage again and returned home.— I reached the lower Bridge across the Neva, just as the Sun was rising at a quarter before four— The lines of Carriages on the road were almost uninterrupted from Peterhoff to the City Gate; and they were often two or three in front— I pass’d upwards of two thousand as I presume on the road; and during the first half of the way great multitudes of people returning on foot.— The numbers of People who attend at this celebration, are asserted to be at least fifty thousand. It has been usual to keep such a day here ever since Peter the first’s time, but the day has occasionally been changed— I was present at this fête in the year 1782—but it was then kept on the festival of St: Peter and St: Paul. the 29th: of June Old Stile; being the then Grand Duke Paul’s name day. He was not present however, being then upon his travels— The day is now changed to that of St Mary Magdalen, which is the Empress-Mother’s, and her daughter Mary’s name day.— the 22. of July old Stile— The time is much better for an illumination, as there are now two hours in the Night, of darkness sufficient for the effect of the Lamps—on the 29th: of June there is no darkness at-all— Accordingly the effect of the illumination this time was far more brilliant than from my recollection it was when I saw it before— There were then I think no fire-works— The Company then was I think more numerous, and from my impressions more splendid in dress— Perhaps however it was because then magnificence of dress was not so familiar and common an object to me as it now is— I saw the Court then only at a distance and as a stranger.— At present I knew all the principal individuals— The Empresses and Grand Duchesses were attired with great splendor of jewels— The Empress Mother wore an imperial Diadem entirely set in Diamonds and of immense Cost— The men were all plainly dress’d; with the uniforms slightly embroidered.— The Ball finished much earlier now, than formerly. The Emperor abridges all these tedious festivities— On arriving at the lower Bridge I found, as Miss Gourieff had told me, that it was raised— I went to the upper Bridge and found it in the same situation— I now learnt, and not without concern that they raise both the Bridges every morning at two O’Clock, to let the vessels pass through, and that they are kept raised from two to three hours— I was detained at them about an hour; and reached my house about a quarter before five O’Clock in the Morning— The weather had been fine the whole day and Night. But I found a surtout convenient in the Carriage, as I returned— As soon as I got home I went to bed, and rose again about eleven. The day was not very industriously employed— I wrote two or three short letters, and read one of Massillon’s Synodial Discourses— Mr: Harris spent the Evening with us.

5. I had a visit this morning from Count Lüxbourg, who is going away in a few days— He waits only for the arrival of his successor, a Count Jennison, who was coming from Berlin; but was stop’d at Polangen, and not allowed to proceed untill a Passport from Count Romanzoff could be sent to him— Lüxbourg took leave of the Court, yesterday week; and he says that the Emperor after charging him with his compliments to the king of Bavaria, said to him—J’espere que la paix du Nord de l’Europe ne sera pas troublée— Il y a beaucoup de discours dans le public; mais tout cela ne signifie rien— A quoi bon feroit on la guerre— Il est tems qu’on commence a se tenir tranquille— On ne croit pas, sans doute faire des conquetes ici—à quoi cela pourroit il mener— Au reste nous sommes prêts— Lüxbourg says that he was quite surprized and embarrassed at hearing the Emperor speak to him in this manner, and hardly knew how to answer him— He told him however that the Sentiments so worthy of a great Monarch, he presumed were also shared by the other side (de l’autre part) and that peace was undoubtedly the object most desirable for suffering humanity.— He says too that he has written an account of this conversation to his Government, leaving out however the expressions which import a readiness for war— I should have thought them by far the most important part of the report.— Captain Woodberry also called upon me to ask my opinion whether it would be safe for him to sail for America— He says there are letters from Mr Williams in London, saying that War between Great-Britain and the United States, is inevitable, and that he expects an order for capturing and detaining all American vessels will very shortly be issued from the British Admiralty. I told him that I could not undertake to advise him without more particular and direct information than I have yet received— After dinner I took a walk of two hours to the island of Jelagin— While I was gone, Count Bose, and Mr Fisher and Mr: Dugan paid us visits— Mr Jones and Mr Moses had been, and came again after I returned— I wrote a Note to Count Romanzoff requesting to see him, and received his answer appointing to-morrow half past twelve at Noon to receive me.

6. According to appointment I went at half past twelve O’Clock to Count Romanzoff’s— I reminded him of a Note which soon after my arrival here I had written him respecting the Commerce, and the Hector, and mentioned that I had lately received a letter from one of the owners making enquiries what was done with those cases— He asked me if I had never received from him any Answer relating to them— I said I had not— He said he would immediately attend to it— That it had been referred to the Minister of Marine, and no report had yet been made by him.— I spoke of a packet which I sent him in the beginning of June, for Mr: Russell at Paris, which was to go by a Courier, and as I had just received from Mr: Russell a letter, by which it appeared that packet had not come to his hands, I was afraid that by some accident, or perhaps some mistake of my Servant, the Count had not received it— He said that he had; but the delay in its transmission to Mr: Russell had arisen from another accident— An extraordinary length of time during which his Courier had been detained before he had dispatched him— It was full two months after the time he had intended— Prince Kurakin complained of it very much, but after all those discussions had arisen the Emperor had positively determined that he would not come to any definitive Resolution to be communicated by Courier, untill he should know of the Duke of Vicence’s arrival at Paris, and what effect would be produced by his return— The Courier therefore had not been dispatched untill the day of the Te Deum, and probably has but just now arrived at Paris.— I said that with regard to the preparation of a Treaty of Commerce, I had made no further Communication to him, owing to the uncertainty both in the state of public affairs and of my own situation here; not knowing what the ultimate disposition of my Government with regard to this mission had been or would be— He said that from this uncertainty in the State of every thing it seemed really impossible to enter upon any discussion relative to Commerce— We could not know from day to day whether there would be any Commerce— It was impossible to do any thing more than provide for the day that was passing over our heads— What would come to-morrow, was beyond all human foresight. What for instance would be the consequence of a War between the United States and England, which I had told him I thought probable, and which he thought so himself— However amicably disposed they were here to favour our Commerce, and they continued as much so as they ever had been, it would obviously upon that contingency be totally stop’d by the English— He was therefore sorry to see this prospect of that War; for it protracted all the hopes of Peace, and menaced a longer and more extensive War— Did not I think so?— What was my opinion of the chances for a Peace? (This fashion of Consultation is one of the Count’s forms of Civility— He supposes that I feel flattered by having my Opinion asked, and that it will make me talk as much as he pleases— I always do give him my opinions as freely as he asks them; not that I fancy he attaches so much importance to them, as he imagines I do, but because I consider it as civility returned for civility, and because as long as my talk is not tiresome to him, I suppose it to be agreeable) I asked him if he meant a general Peace?— Ay, or at least a Peace between France and England?— That was the same thing; I saw nothing like a prospect of it, or a disposition to it on either side; there never was less reason to expect it— he said he was extremely sorry to be so nearly of my opinion— And I was extremely sorry to hear His Excellency acknowledge it; for it confirmed me in a belief, which I should have been most happy to have had him shake— But it was too clear— The Emperor Napoleon, and his Minister Montalivet spoke of the War in Spain as likely still to occupy several campaigns— They talked of ten years more of War, as of a matter for which France was prepared— No symptom of relaxation or yielding could be discovered there— In England such symptoms must come first from the People; as long as their Spirits could be kept up their Government would not flinch; and as long as they had any successes to boast of the Spirits of the people would not flag.— There was no appearance of that kind yet— No petitions for Peace— No talk of a change of Ministry— There was indeed great anxiety for the issue of affairs in Spain and Portugal; and untill that affair was finished the English Nation would not begin to look round them and think of Peace— The Count said that France was certainly now making another great effort there— Besides the success of their arms in taking Tarragona, and the junction of the two Marshals Soult and Marmont, he knew that the Emperor Napoleon had determined to send eighty thousand more men into Spain— The English army would probably be obliged to resume its old position near Lisbon, and there, time again might be gained— For it was remarkable that the Emperor Napoleon who was always accustomed to announce quick dispatch, and to threaten with thunderbolt’s, had in this case admitted that the subjugation of Spain would still be an affair of time— He then asked me whether I knew, if Mr Bezerra had any late news; and what his opinion was of the present state of things— I said that I had not seen Mr Bezerra since the Peterhoff day, when he did not know of Lord Wellington’s retreat— The Count then told me that the Ambassador had just been with him— He had received a Courier who brought him the account that the Ecclesiastical Council, assembled at Paris had been dissolved; and three of the Bishops arrested. He was
a little surprized at this instance of resistance to the will of the Emperor Napoleon; but he did not expect it would be followed by any serious consequences— He believed there was very little religion in France— When he was last there he had made it a particular object of his personal observation— He had supposed before he went there that the result of the horrible Revolution through which they had pass’d would have been to awaken religious ideas in the people, and have given their minds a peculiar direction that way— He saw no such thing— He saw no disposition with regard to religion but that of profound indifference— It was not a fashion of infidelity such as had been known in France thirty or forty years ago— Not a sectarian Atheism, courting martyrdom; but total indifference—a total absence of all thought concerning religion. He had mentioned it to the Emperor Napoleon, and had perceived that the remark had displeased him— He had asked him on what he founded his opinion—the Count answered that as he had before going to France entertained the theoretic idea that he should find strong symptoms of religious propensities, he had made it a point to observe, and had repeatedly gone into the principal churches of Paris on Sundays and Holidays in service time— They were all absolutely deserted. Scarcely a Soul to be seen; except here and there an occasional straggler, who looked as if he had been sent upon an errand, and had come into the Church and taken a chair to rest himself on the way.— The Emperor had replied—Perhaps it may be so, but I assure you it is not my fault— On the contrary I know the importance of religious sentiments, and encourage the propagation of them as much as I can— There are even five or six popular writers to whom I give pensions for this purpose, and among them are Chateaubriant and Madame de Genlis— Now said the Count, he considers these people as drugs of the imperial pharmacopaea—ingredients to be mixed up in the chemical mass of an Emperor’s Government— His own idea is political and not at-all religious— And as to his Pensioners, for aught I know, Chateaubriand may be honest, but Madame de Sillery would preach any religion for which she could get paid— I know something of her, and I know her to be as false and unprincipled a woman as breathes.— I said that Chateaubriant himself had lately shewn some resistance against the Emperor’s will, as I had heard, on a religious topic—that he had written a discourse for his reception as a member of the National Institute which he had not been suffered to pronounce, and which he had refused to alter— The Count said it was not a matter of religion— It related to the death of the king— Chateaubriant was received at the Academy in the place of Chénier— Chenier had voted in the Convention for the king’s Death, and Chateaubriant instead of pronouncing a panegyric upon Chénier, according to custom, had written a violent philippic against him, and criminated him especially for his vote on the king’s trial— The Emperor had forbidden its being delivered; because he Napoleon had pardoned, all those who had voted for the king’s Death, and had among them several of his highest imperial Officers— Cambacérès was one— Regnaud de St: Jean d’Angely was another— He did not chuse therefore that any such allusion to that Event should be made in a public Oration; especially by a man whom he patronized, and to whom he had been a benefactor— The Count added that he did think there was something very indecent in the manner in which they managed some of these Academical receptions in France— He had attended one of them, where a man, whose name he did not recollect was received in the place of a certain physician named Cabanis, who had written an Atheistical Book— The new member had observed the custom of eulogizing his predecessor, but the President, in answering the discourse had severely censured him for praising such a Book—for the recipiendary had included the book in his panegyric— The Count added, laughing, that these reception speeches and Answers had been well ridiculed by Piron, who said that they all amounted exactly to this that the member said “Messieurs, je vous remercie,” and the President answered “Monsieur, il n’y a pas de quoi”— This Academy had occasioned him to make another indiscreet observation in conversing with the Emperor Napoleon— They had on some occasion, while he was at Paris, perhaps some affair of the Spanish business, sent a deputation to the Emperor, and the orator of the deputation had said among other things that “they were an invisible militia surrounding his throne”— The speech was published in the next morning’s Moniteur, where the Count read it— Seeing afterwards the Emperor the same day, he had told him that there had been to him a deputation from the Academy, and that he encouraged and countenanced those people— I am not said the Count remarkable for being incautious in what I say; but that day somehow it happened that all my caution forsook me— For, I said, yes, Sire, and I have read something as a speech of that deputation which struck me oddly, and gave me some pain— And what is that, said the Emperor?— Why, Sire, they said they were an invisible militia surrounding your throne— The meaning of which is that your throne derives support and assistance from a club of atheists— Now I think in the first place this is not true; and in the next, if it were, that it is not becoming that it should be thus publicly announced— The Emperor made little reply, but I saw said the Count, that what I had said was not agreeable to him— The next day however the Orator’s Speech was published again in another Gazette, and the
passage upon which I had animadverted, was omitted— I have no doubt that my remarks to the Emperor had occasioned its being struck out.— Ever since my return from France at that time I have been persuaded that there was very little religion there— Now indeed, this incident in the Council disconcerts a little my ideas (“dérange un peu mes idées”) and we shall see what it comes to—but again I have considered that the Council consisting principally of old men, may naturally have an extraordinary proportion of members more stubborn than the Spirit of the times will be found to bear them out.— The characteristic of the great mass was indifference; and it was not confined to France— It pervaded the great Body of the Roman Catholics throughout Europe.— Consider, said he what the Pope is, in the principles of that sect— You know the situation in which he has long been kept— How but from this immovable indifference can we account for it, that not the slightest manifestation of interest, or of sensibility to his condition has appeared in any part of the Catholic world— Yet the mass of population in several important European States were roman Catholics— To instance only Austria— I said I did not know whether I could without indiscretion tell him what I thought of Austria— But he must be aware, Austria had made her effort—she had struggled—she had motives of policy which would induce her to restrain the expression of Sentiments among her Subjects which might impair her good-understanding with France.— He replied that the Sentiments to which he alluded were precisely of a Nature which the Government could not controul— If they were felt they would burst through all such restraints— He did not know however that any such restraint had been used, or attempted— There certainly had been none here— Several provinces of the Russian Empire were inhabited by Roman Catholics; and the Emperor Napoleon knew; he had long since been informed that if any difference between him and the Pope should arise, by which the Consciences of that Class of the Russian Subjects might be affected, the Russian Government would not side with him against them.— I mentioned to the Count that I had some time since seen a letter from the Roman Catholic Bishops in America to those in Ireland, concerning the situation of the Pope— He had never heard of it, and requested me if it should again fall in my way, to send it to him; which I promised.— In the part of the conversation respecting the prospects of Peace, I told him that besides the War between the United States and England, which with him I feared & lamented would be inevitable, the State of affairs between France and Russia, with the discussions they were agitating, (at least as they were represented in the public opinion) had also a strong appearance of protracting the period when Peace might be expected.— He said that with regard to the relations between Russia and France, there were undoubtedly many unfounded reports in public circulation; but thus much he could say that if the whole budget could be turned inside out ( si on pouvait tourner le fond du sac en dehors) and exposed to the view of every body it would not at-all promote any other conclusion than is already drawn from what is known.— From Count Romanzoff’s I went and called upon Mr Harris, and returned home between 4 and 5. O’Clock— I dined at Baron Blome’s; but arrived so late, that I found the Company already at table— The French Ambassador and all his Legation were there— He told me that he should dispatch a Courier to-morrow or the day after, and offered to send by him any letter that I might wish— He asked us not to engage ourselves for next Saturday, for that he should then give his Grand Diner Diplomatique; and should send his Cards to-morrow— He must give a party too the 15th. and he did not mean to kill two birds with one stone— Afterwards too he should have the Nôce—meaning Mr Rayneval’s Marriage— After dinner I took a long walk to and round the island of Jelagin— On returning home I found Mr Jones on an Evening visit— Madame Colombi had been with the ladies, and I met her as she was going home.

7. Mr Raimbert called on me this morning, with advice of another bill drawn on Messrs: Bainbridge and Brown, to be certified as for Mr: Gray’s account, which I did.— I finished a letter for my brother begun a week since— After dinner I made an attempt at fishing at the end of our wharf; but without success— I soon became weary of it, and walked about an hour— On returning home I found Mr: and Madam Bezerra just leaving our house— Mr Willing also called on me this morning, and expressed his wish to return to Philadelphia, by the Lion which is to sail next week— But he cannot go without having a special Passport— I therefore promised to give him despatches, and to apply for a Messengers Passport, for him— I wrote for one to Count Romanzoff accordingly—

8. My time seems scarcely long enough for my occupations— My journal or one of my letter books is continually falling in arrears. Mr: Smith and Mr: Jones went on a party to Czarsko Zelo— I employed all the morning in writing, but without getting through my task— After dinner I attempted again to fish, but as unsuccessfully as yesterday— I walked round to the river’s bank opposite our house and returned the same way— Between four and five miles— The French Ambassador sent me his Valet de-Chambre to
inform me that he should dispatch his Courier at four O’Clock this afternoon— I therefore wrote shortly to Mr Russell, and sent my letter to the Ambassador in seasonable time. About ten at Night Mr Gray came in with a large bundle of packets and letters. They were brought by Mr: Patterson of Baltimore, who arrived this day from England, having come through Sweden— There were letters and Newspapers from Mr J. S. Smith in London— The same from Mr. Speyer at Stockholm, and a letter from Mr Everett at the same place— There were also two packets for Count Romanzoff, one for Mr: Schoulepoff, one for Mr Lebzeltern, one for Baron Rall, and one for a Mr: Lichtenstein, at Baron Rall’s— I sat up untill between one and two in the morning; reading the Letters and Newspapers.

9. My dispatches were running in my head almost all Night, so that I had no sleep untill four in the morning. I lay accordingly late perhaps untill nine, before I rose.— We had scarcely finished breakfasting before Mr: Woodward came to see me— He had been here perhaps half an hour when Mr: Bentzon came in— This is a Danish Gentleman who belonged to the island of Santa Cruz, and was a member of the Government there untill it was taken by the English— He then went to New-York, and there married a Miss Astor of that City, who is here with him— He came with Mr Erving in the frigate John Adams to L’Orrient, and brought me a letter of Introduction from Judge Livingston. I saw his Lady at the Peterhoff Ball, where she was with Mr Alexander James Smith and his Sisters— I dined with himself at Baron Blome’s, and sat next him at table, but without knowing him— While he was with me Mr Hollins came and introduced to me Mr: Patterson— They were followed by Count Lüxbourg, who brought and introduced to me his Successor as Bavarian Secretary of Legation and Chargé d’Affaires Count Jennison— He had been stop’d at the frontiers, (though with his diplomatic character) because he had not a Passport from Count Romanzoff to come into Russia, and would have been obliged to wait untill this time at Memel; but for the Minister, the Chevalier de Bray, who upon his return to this Country, overtook him there; released him, and took him with him, as part of his suite. He left the Chevalier at Baron Löwenstern’s House in Livonia.— My next visitors were Mr: Fisher and Mr: Roberts, and after them Mr Smith of Boston, Captain Silsbee, and another American whose name though Mr Smith introduced him, escaped me— This Company coming in succession engaged me almost all the morning and untill dinner time— Mr: Harris past the Evening with us— The weather allowed me only a walk shorter than usual after dinner.— Mr. Smith returned from his excursion with Mr Jones to Czarsko-Zelo.

10. The Summer has been hitherto remarkably fine; but the symptoms of its close begin to shew themselves— “The sear and yellow leaf” begins to appear upon the trees, and the rains are setting in to announce the autumn. I dined at the French Ambassador’s—his first great diplomatic dinner— Count Romanzoff asked me to send him the three latest English Newspaper’s; being later than any that he had seen— I accordingly sent them immediately on my return home in the Evening.— At table I sat between the Minister of War, Genl: Barclay de Tolly, and the Emperor’s Aid de Camp, Count Ozarowsky— My only Conversation was with the latter— I mentioned to him, that the late king of Sweden had returned from Heligoland into Holstein, greatly incensed, against the English Governor & Officers of the island— The Count said he was the most difficult man to deal with, that he had ever met in the course of his life.— When he came into Russia last Autumn, the Emperor sent him Count Ozarowsky to meet and compliment him— His orders were to do every thing that the king pleased, and to facilitate any thing upon which he should determine— Whether he chose to stay at Riga, or to come to St: Petersburg, or to go into the interior of Russia, or to embark for England, his pleasure was to be the rule for Ozarowsky’s conduct— But he was scarcely ever six hours together of the same intention— At one time he was for staying at Riga— Then for going to Sarepta a Herrnhuth establishment— Then for going to Bender; because Charles 12 had been there; and lastly for going to England, and then to Spain— He did actually go to England, but did not stay there long— He came thence to Heligoland, and now has returned to the Continent—the Count says that he is disordered in the Intellect; to such a degree that he sometimes fancies himself to be Charles 12 in person— And that was his motive for intending to go to Bender— A project which he carried so far that the horses and Carriage were already tackled for his departure before he changed his mind— He has a sort of Bible, or rather a Herrnhuth Calendar, with a text from the Bible for every day in the year— He consults this Book every day as an oracle, and considers the text for the day as prescribing to him his rule of conduct for that day— But as he gives a sort of mystical construction to these texts, he makes out of them a meaning of his own, which instead of inspiring wisdom, as the natural operation of the Bible would be, leads him into a multitude of absurdities— Yet he has withal many good qualities— A proud Spirit of honour, and generous sentiments.
Immediately after dinner I left the Ambassador’s and after calling at Mr Harris’s to take the letters left for me there, I returned home— I found only a letter from my Mother dated 22. September 1810— In the Evening we had visits from Mr: Labouchere & Mr: Bethman, and from Mr Jones and Mr Patterson— Mrs Adams since the morning has confined herself to her chamber, and this afternoon sent for her nurse.

11. My wife confined herself to her chamber all this day, and this Evening sent for Mrs Reineke, who came about nine O’Clock and determined to pass the Night here— There was rain during so great a part of the day, that I found only an opportunity to walk about an hour in the botanical Garden. Madame Colombi came with Mrs: Bentzon, and introduced her to Catherine— Mrs: Adams could not see her— Madam de Betancourt and her two daughters were also here— They have been to be presented to the Empress on the occasion of the General’s receiving the red ribband.— I employed part of the day in writing— Read Massillon’s two last Synodial discourses— On the necessity of prayer; and on the duty of the Clergy to attend upon the sick— Also a Discourse on certain abuses which had crept in among the Clergy of his diocese— The Bishop always appears a wise, humble, and benevolent man, upon all occasions except when politics or controversial religion are concerned— They seem entirely to change his Nature. I read also two sections 33. and 34 of Robinson’s character of Christ—a part of my reading which has been improperly intermitted these three weeks.

12. I bless God, for the birth of a daughter this Evening, at seven O’Clock— My wife had been taken with short pains from 7. in the morning and indeed quite unwell the greatest part of last Night. from 11. in the Morning the pains had been sharp, and in the afternoon they were extremely severe— I was in her chamber from time to time during the whole day, and had been but a few minutes from it, when Catherine came into my room, and told me that I had a daughter. In the anxiety and fear that she might have a long and critical labour I had sent Waldstein immediately after dinner for Dr: Galloway— He came about nine in the Evening, two hours after the child was born. He had little to prescribe— Mrs Adams was as well as the circumstances admitted. I wrote immediately to her mother and to my own, to give them the information— Which employed me untill Midnight— Mr: Montreal had been here this morning before Breakfast— Mr: Hall came afterwards to inform me that he was about to sail in the Horace for Boston, and to ask for my letters— Mr: Plummer, Mr: Ashton and a Captain Marks visited me next— Captain Marks is master of an vessel called the Angerone, arrived at Cronstadt, pretending to be an American, but having as Mr Fisher to whom she was addressed, informed me a Register forged in London— He had first met some difficulty with the neutral Commission, but contrived to get over that— Afterwards when his papers were to be sent to Mr Harris by whom they would have been detected, he told Sparrow at Cronstadt that he had lost them with other valuable papers, and advertised a reward to any body who should find, and return them to him— As he cannot go away without papers he came now to ask assistance of me to get him out of his difficulty— I stated to him explicitly that I had been informed that he came with a forged register—that I had heard of it before there was any allegation of the loss of his papers— He said if his Register was forged it was not to his knowledge— That he received it from Mr Maury at Liverpool; that the ship was his own, and he had purchased it of a Mr Jamieson— The papers he believed had also pass’d through the hands of Mr Lyman at London— He answered however concerning the forged Register with so much hesitation, and with so much stammering about the loss of his papers, as confirmed the information given me by Mr Fisher.— He told me that Mr Fisher had a letter giving it as a reason why the vessel had been chartered at so high a freight, because it was a genuine American vessel— But he intimated that as freight was now much lower here, it was Mr Fisher’s interest to dissolve the contract for the freight if he could— He asked me if his giving Bonds to produce a true register in future would answer— I thought not, but referred him to Mr. Harris the Consul, to whose province this business belongs; assuring him that however inclined and bound I was to give all my assistance to my Countrymen in misfortune here, I could not interfere in his favour under the Circumstances in which he appears— Mr: Patterson came and mentioned that he found himself in an unpleasant situation—having the charge of two vessels at Archangel, laden with Coffee, upon which eighty thousand dollars of duties were to be paid, and which would not sell for the duties— He wished to petition for an allowance of time to pay the duties— Mr Harris mentioned to me some time since that he intended to apply to the Minister of Finance for a general indulgence of the same kind, for many Americans lately arrived, and all equally needing it— I recommended Mr Patterson to consult Mr Harris, and assured him of any assistance that I could give.— Mr Harris and Mr Fisher called in the Evening, but were not admitted— I had given orders that no person should be received. I received a letter, and some newspapers from Mr Erving at Copenhagen.

13. My dear wife was excessively ill great part of the Night, and almost the whole of this day— She suffers in the same manner as she did at the birth of our eldest Son George.— I found her at the worst on going to her chamber this morning— In the course of the day her sufferings subsided; but at Night again she was in so much pain and uneasiness as gave me great anxiety.— I wrote to Mr Erving, and gave a Passport to the black man
in the Emperor’s service, Claude Gabriel, who is going to Providence, Rhode-Island to bring his wife and children with him back— I dined at Mr Meyer’s, with a Company of fourteen persons; among whom were the Chevaliers Bezerra, and Navarro; Mr Labouchere, Mr Harris and Captain Bainbridge— Mr Harris told me that he should take Captain Marks’s bonds to produce a genuine Register for his vessel in future, at which I was a little surprized, and suggested to him some objections to this course— He informed me however that as it was a matter within his province, he had determined upon it, and he hoped it would have my approbation— Not as I am at present advised— Mr Bezerra and Mr Labouchere had some warm political Conversation— Poor Navarro always looks in pain when he hears Bezerra talk.

14. I pass’d a Night of great anxiety on account of my wife, but she is in some degree relieved, and much better this day than yesterday. Dr: Galloway was here this morning, and Mr Fisher and Mr Blodget in the Evening— After dinner I took a walk with Catherine, on the River’s Bank, and in the Botanical Garden. I spoke to Mr Fisher about Captain Marks, for whom Fisher told me he had refused to give Bonds— He said that it was from the neutral Commission itself that he was informed Marks’s Register was a forgery; but he had not seen the papers himself— I wrote several short letters, and brought up other arrears.

15. Mr: Hall came this morning, and took the remaining letters that I had ready for Boston— He is going in the Horace Captain Leach; and was to go down to Cronstadt this Evening. Captain Leach himself afterwards came with Mr: Woodward, and told me he had got the package of linen for my Mother— It being the Emperor Napoleon’s birth-day, I dined in formal Ceremony at the French Ambassador’s— It was like the dinner on the same occasion last year; but Count Lauriston’s magnificence is not in so high a Style as that of the Duke de Vicence— The Ceremony of rising to drink the Emperor’s health in Champaign Wine was repeated in the same manner as then— And there was a band of music occasionally performing during the dinner— The preparations for the illumination were like those of that Night. I sat between Counts Soltikoff and Bussche at table.— The Company were about fifty-five persons— The dinner was short, and the company all very soon afterwards retired— I called at Mr Harris’s house and took the letters and newspapers that were there for me— Returned home, and took an Evening walk to Count Strogonoff’s Garden— A number of visitors called while I was absent— Of visitors both morning and Evening we continue to have more than I have time to allow them— Mrs: Adams was this day better; but still confined entirely to her bed, and not able to sit up even in that—the child is well.

16. I received a note from Count Maistre the Sardinian Minister, requesting me to return him his manuscript Translation of Plutarch’s Treatise on the delays of divine Justice; which he lent me some weeks ago— I have been read it, and been pleased with his preface and Notes— The translation is too much dilated— The argument against Wittenbach to prove that the Christian Scriptures were known to Plutarch is weak— He commends Wittenbach’s learning, and ingenuity, but censures his infidelity.— There are two points in the character of Plutarch’s style, which the french denominate bonhommie and naïveté—they are well represented in the old Translation of Amyot, but I do not find them in that of Count Maistre. He has doubtless corrected some mistakes, and elucidated some obscure passages— Plutarch reasons well but leaves much of the mysterious veil over his subject which nothing but Christian Doctrine can remove— If the existence of Man was limited to this life,—it would be impossible for me to believe the Universe under any moral Government. Prudence would be the only God, and Jupiter according to the pagan Doctrine, would be subject to Fate.— It is not the affliction of the righteous, but the prosperity of the wicked, which would contribute most to stagger my faith in divine Justice— I cannot reconcile it to my own mind to see the Crimes of a successful Conqueror, punished in the person of his innocent great-grand child, and to take it for Justice.— There is one more idea which I think not unimportant— Taking a future state of retribution for granted, the imperfection of divine Justice in the present life, necessarily follows— If it were complete here, there would be nothing to compensate hereafter— If the righteous were rewarded, and the wicked punished in this world, to the full extent of Justice, there would be neither merit nor demerit left, upon which Justice could operate hereafter— Now, let it once be admitted that there is a balance of virtue and of vice to be accounted for and settled in another state of existence, and there will be no question left with regard to the delays of divine Justice— Because however defective the measure may be found here, the principle supposes that it will be filled up elsewhere— I sent Count Maistre his Book with a Note of thanks— Mr Willing called upon me, and informed me that he should return to the United States, not in the Lion but in the Bengall; the vessel in which he came— I gave him the Courier’s Passport, with the packet from Count Romanzoff, and that of my own dispatches for the Secretary of State— Mr: Harris was here in the Evening. He has concluded not to take Marks’s bond.

17. Mr: Raimbert and Mr: Montreal paid me a visit of compliment this morning— Mr Fisher and Dugan afterwards called here— Mr: Dugan very imprudently last winter gave a bond that a certain quantity of indigo and pepper, which had first been exported from Calcutta to America, and which he had imported here, was exported from Calcutta in time of Peace—that is, Between Russia and Britain—though he knew it was really exported since the War commenced— He is now much alarmed about the forfeiture of the bond, and came to ask my advice, and interposition, to obtain relief from his difficulty. The bond was given by a man at Liebau where the goods were, by a power of attorney from Mr Von Essen, one of the partners of Fisher’s house— The house are therefore bound, and Mr: Dugan who wants to go home, cannot pay over to Dugan the proceeds of the sales of the goods without security to be indemnified from the bond— They intended a petition to the Minister of Finance, to be relieved, and I promised to give them all the assistance in my power by speaking to the Minister— But the case seems a desperate one— I wrote a letter to the President U.S— After dinner I went with Catherine to the Hotel de l’Europe to visit Mr and Mrs: Bentzon— We saw only the Lady who is young and handsome— We also went to see Mr: and Madame Bezerra, but they were not at home— We called at Mr Harris’s to ask for my letters and papers from the Post-Office but there were none— Just after our return home Mr & Madame Bezerra came in and made us a short visit— Madame Bezerra was admitted to Mrs: Adams’s chamber— Mrs Krehmer and her daughter had been before while I was out. Mrs Adams is better but yet very weak

18. A morning visit from Mr Lassalette, a young frenchman, Supercargo of an American vessel; the Zodiac, arrived from Cronstadt, at New-York— I read the morning Church Service in my wife’s chamber.— Dined at Baron Blome’s, with a small company— Mr Tatischeff, General Watzdorf and Count Bose, the two young Gourieffs and some others were there— After dinner Mr Lebzeltern came in with the Chevalier de Stürmer, a new attaché to the Austrian Legation— We dined in the house; the weather being too damp and cold for the tent— I came home early and walked down to the Wiburg Bridge and back. In the Evening I read the Sections 35 and 36. of Robinson’s character of Christ, and the first Sermon of the English preacher— It is by Tillotson, and upon the superior excellence of the Christian Religion— Mrs: Adams sat up this day several hours—the first time she has left her bed since her confinement— She recovers very slowly— It is Charles’s birth-day— He is four years old, and measures 3. f. 1 3/4 inches.— the air of the Country appears favourable to his health and growth.

19. The day pass’d, morning and evening without visitors— I employed it principally in writing, and in regulating my monthly accounts— After dinner I took the walk of ten Wersts, down to the Wiburg Bridge and up through Count Stroganoff’s garden and over the two Kammenoi-Ostroff Bridges, home— Met the Empress and Princess Amelia riding on horseback, but it was so dark that I did not recognize them— Miss Gourieff was with them.— My wife sat up part of the day, and walked once across her chamber.

20. Mr: Webb came and took my last despatch to the Secretary of State, with some other letters— He informed me that by the Accounts of Captains just arrived at Cronstadt, the Concordia, Captain Johnson bound from thence to New-York, has been taken by the English, and sent into Gothenburg, and that two of the vessels which last sailed, the Augustus Captain Flint and Jewel, Captain Robinson have been taken into Hangöe near Carlshamm— Mr Webb intends notwithstanding this, to sail immediately in the John Adams— Mr Fisher and Mr Dugan were here afterwards— They have not yet concluded how to frame their petition to be released from the inconsiderate Bond given last winter for Mr Dugan’s merchandize— Mr Fisher read me the draft of the petition which they have made; but it is in very general terms praying to be released from the Bond, without specifically stating the point in question— After dinner I walked with Catherine in the Botanic garden; and afterwards alone.— Mrs: Adams was up almost the whole of this day, and walked several times about her chamber— But in the evening she was much fatigued, and not so well as for some days.

21. Mr: Montreal breakfasted with us. I paid a visit to the French Ambassador, but he sent me an excuse for not receiving me— I also left Cards at Count St: Julien’s, for him and for the Chevalier de Stürmer, and at the Chevalier de Bray’s, for Count Jennison the Bavarian Secretary of Legation— Count Luxbourg left this City the 12th: instt:— I visited Mr Navarro, but he was not at home— With Mr: & Madame Bezerra, I found Mr Labouchère, who read me a passage from a letter he had received from Amsterdam, which shocked me exceedingly— It related that Mr: William Six, who was the last Minister from Holland here, and with whom I was while he resided here on such friendly terms, had been found one morning at four O’Clock, drowned in a Canal near his house at Amsterdam— That he had gone out from his house at half past 9 O’Clock the Evening before— That he had not been robb’d, and that for some weeks before it had been remarked that he had an appearance of gloom and discontent— The letter and Labouchere both intimated the belief that he had voluntarily done this act, which I am unwilling to credit— Labouchere says that he was poor— That he was supposed to have saved something by his mission here; but that he
had nothing else— That he had only 12000 livres a year by the place that had been given him, of Intendant des Domaines, which was a very subordinate Office—merely as a Clerk to Daru— And that perhaps Daru might have found fault with something in his management of the Domaines— Labouchere is no friend to Six and I hope that his conjectures are unfounded— He was not a man from whose character such an act of desperation could be expected— He was not so poor as Labouchere supposes, and being a bachelor, had no family to bear as a burden upon his estate or his spirits— He was undoubtedly much reduced from the situation in which he had been here, and in his own Country before; and he had set his heart perhaps too much upon personal distinctions— But he was as the Duke de Vicence once said of him to me un peu Optimiste— He had the peculiar faculty of looking at the fair side of things; and was one of the last men, of all whom I ever knew, of whom I should have expected self-violence or despondency— It is in every point of view more probable, that in the darkness of the Night he fell by accident into the Canal, than that he rushed wilfully upon his own fate— At all events it is a catastrophe that I deplore.— I saw Mr: Plincke my late land lord, and asked him if he had finished his bargain for his house. He said no; nor was he likely to finish it at-all— He apologized to me for the short Notice he had given me to quit the house, which he declared was in consequence of an express message sent him by Mr Kosodawleff the Minister of the Interior to give such notice to all his tenants, which that Minister had since denied— That he had been to him with the very person by whom the message was sent, who attested the fact in his presence to Mr Kosodawleff himself, which produced another explanation between that Minister and the Messenger— That he, Plincke considered himself as excessively ill-used, and if Mr: Kosodawleff did not immediately come to some arrangement, he should make a statement of the facts, and request it might be laid before the Emperor himself.— I told Mr Plincke that after the first moment of displeasure that I had felt and expressed without disguise to him, on receiving so short notice to quit, and in the then condition of my family; when I found the house which I now occupy empty, and that I could remove into it, I had got over all resentment— That if he should finally not sell the house, I would return to it under my lease, deducting of course the rent which would have accrued during the time that we are not in the house— He said that he should be extremely happy to have me return upon these terms— I called upon Mr Harris, but he was gone to Cronstadt. I took at his house my letters and papers; among which was a letter from Mr: Erving of the 9th: of this month from Copenhagen notifying me of the capture of two American vessels by a privateer under French Colours— The vessels carried into Copenhagen; and the papers sent to Paris— He supposes the same privateer, will carry in vessels bound from this Country to America— I immediately went to Mr: Webb and read the letter to him—he is going in the John Adams; and I advised him if he could help it not to suffer himself to be taken by this privateer— I returned home and wrote a letter to Mr Harris enclosing an extract of almost the whole of Mr Erving’s letter, and requesting him to communicate the information to the masters of the American vessels at Cronstadt, and other persons interested, and also if he thinks proper to the Consular Agents at Riga and Revel— I walked from the St. Isaacs square home; and after dinner walked again in the Botanical Garden; alone— This is the ninth day since my wife’s confinement— She is now remarkably well, and the child also.

22. I was this morning without interruption, and employed it in writing, excepting that I was diverted from my employment for as much as two hours by an American pamphlet. After dinner I walked with Catherine and Charles in the Botanical garden, untill dark. The days are already so much shortened that there is very little time to walk after dinner— Mr Fisher and Mr Ashton spent an hour with us in the Evening— Mr: and Madame Bezerra called while we were out. Mr Smith and Mr Gray dined abroad.

23. Mr Montreal called this morning while we were at breakfast. The rest of the morning I was alone, and wrote— After dinner Mrs Bentzon came and rode with Catherine to Kammenoi-Ostroff— Mr Hollins and Mr: Roberts were here about an hour in the Evening— I walked in Count Stroganoff’s Garden, and finished reading Ramsey’s life of Washington in a French Translation—the Book was lent me by Mr Laval who had been very much pleased with it. Mrs: Adams was unwell with a severe head-ache the whole day. I neither read nor write a fourth part so much as I ought, and yet I seem to myself to lead a laborious life.

24. Mr Plummer and Mr Lander were here this morning— Mr Lander embarks immediately for Boston in a vessel called the Sachem, and is very anxious about escaping from the pretended french privateer out of Copenhagen— I made up a packet for the
Secretary of State, and enclosing with it a duplicate to the President, and letters for Mr Eustis, Secretary at War, and for Mrs Johnson sent it to Mr Wallace who is just about embarking for Baltimore in the Argus. I wasted so much of my time in this manner that I wrote but little, and that little was unwise— I began a letter to J. S. Smith in London, and wrote with so little reflection that on reading it over I thought best to strike out at least three quarters of what I had written— This very seldom happens to me— Not that I always write with Prudence, but that I incur without scruple some risks, and generally intend to be cautious— After dinner I walked my rounds, over the kammenoi-ostrof and Wyburg bridges— When I came home I found Mr Jones and Mr Fisher, who spent an hour of the Evening with us. Mrs Adams was so well as to see them.

25. A cold storm with an East-wind the whole day— I had no Company in the morning— Mr: Smith dined abroad— Mrs: Bentzon was here at tea. I altered and finished my letter to Mr J. S. Smith, and wrote to Mr Erving— I read the Sections 37. 38. and 39. of Robinson’s character of Jesus Christ, and Tillotson’s Sermon upon the Peace of the Christian Religion— I had read this before in Tillotson’s works, where it is entire— In this compilation it is abridged.— I had only a short walk half an hour before dinner.

26. The storm continued great part of the day, and the weather is so cold that it was scarcely possible to sit and write without a fire— After Sunset, and in the Evening it had the appearance of clearing away.— I walked nearly an hour before, and about as much after dinner. Mr: and Madame Bezerra paid us a visit in the Evening— Mr Bezerra was very full of four store-ships, said to have arrived at Revel from England, as well as of a paragraph in an English paper which says that there is a perfect understanding between the English and Russian Governments, and that these store-ships are laden with arms and ammunition to be used against the common Enemy.— Mr Harris afterwards came in, and says it is nothing at All— That Mr Borel and Mr Schulepoff both assure him there is nothing in it— Mr Harris brought me several letters; and among them one from Mr Everett, with an abstract of the late publication of Mr R. Smith the ex-Secretary of State; written in his own vindication— I employed most of the day in writing.

27. Mr Montreal was here this morning and informed me that these vessels arrived at Revel, brought lead, and perhaps some sulphur and saltpetre, of all which articles there was now a great scarcity, and which could hardly be imported but from England— That Mr Krehmer had a contract for supplying these Articles, and that as he procured them at a low price he had a tacit permission to introduce a certain quantity of English goods with them. I went into the City— Called upon Mr Meyer and afterwards upon Mr Harris— I had some conversation with him respecting the Crescent, a vessel which now appears to have come here with a spurious Captain.— Also concerning a sailor who has written to me from Revel— He lent me an American Newspaper, the Aurora of 26. June, containing Mr R. Smith’s Vindication of his Resignation. I went round by the Shops, saw the people demolishing the Steeple of the Old Casan Church, and walked home from the Summer-Garden-Bridge— In the Evening I walked again to Kammenoi Ostroff, and was caught in a shower of rain— Mr Jones pass’d the Evening here untill near Midnight.

28. Mr Montreal came again this Morning, with some further information concerning the vessels arrived at Revel, and spoke to me of a publication which he had heard was in an English newspaper, and with which my name was said to be connected— I did not know to what he referred, but Mr Harris afterwards in the course of the day sent me the London Courier of 30. July, containing the publication. It is a stupid forgery, purporting to be a Memoir, signed by the Duke de Cadore 30. October 1810. addressed to the Russian Ambassador Prince Kurakin, to be laid before the Emperor of Russia— It contains a clumsy imitation of the general accusations of France against Britain and British policy, and asserts the necessity of changing the English Constitution or the Dynasty on the throne— But for the rest it speaks in language suited only to the sentiments of George Rose or any other ministerial tool. Its venom against the United States would be sufficient to betray its English origin— This miserable thing the Courier, a Ministerial Paper, announces with complete solemnity as perhaps the most important State Paper, ever laid before the English Nation; asserts repeatedly that it is of unquestionable authenticity, and gives what it calls a history of its publication— That it was sent by Prince Kurakin to St. Petersburg, where not producing upon the mind of the Emperor Alexander the intended effect, it was communicated by the Russian Government to me— That I sent a copy of it to my Government and to my father, through whom it was first published— This is lie, from beginning to end.— I sent back to Mr Harris as he requested the Paper, and also the Aurora that he had lent me yesterday, with three bills of Exchange, signed for Messrs: Meyer and Brüxner— Catherine and myself only dined together— I walked after dinner in Count Stroganoff’s garden— Met the Empress several times, riding in her Coach— Also the french Ambassador, who told me they had the wedding, meaning I suppose that of Rayneval and Miss Alexandrine Vlodek, yesterday. After I returned home we had visits, first from Commodore Bainbridge, Mr: Calhoun,
Mr Roberts, and Mr Saltus, and afterwards from Captain Boit and Mr Fisher.— The day being fine and the weather warm Mrs Adams rode out, the first time since her confinement.

29. Mr Fisher called upon me this morning with a Mr Connell of Philadelphia. This Gentleman has just arrived by land, from Prussia, where he came from Sweden— I dined at Count Romanzoff’s in the Country— The Ambassador and his Aid de Camp Longuerue— Baron Blome, Count St: Julien and Mr Lebzeltern, Count Schenk and Mr Gremp, The Minister of Police Balascheff, Prince Korzakoff, Mr Bezerra, Mr Schulepoff, Mr Labouchere, and Mr Bethman, Mr Harris and his nephew, Mr Laval and Count Jennison, constituted the Company. The Ambassador spoke to me about the pretended Memoir in the English paper, connected with my name; but he had not seen it— He was to see it this evening, and promised to call upon me to-morrow at Noon— I asked Count Romanzoff about the Sonnas, the supposed tribe of Christians upon the Caucasus— He knew nothing about them but promised to enquire, if I would give him a minute of them— At table I sat between Count St: Julien and Mr Bezerra— The Count was good humoured as usual, and not quite so licentious in his conversation— He says a Lady here told him that he had the reputation of talking about nothing but women; and he seems to have felt the reproof. Mr Bezerra has got over a little of his enthusiasm about the vessels arrived at Revel— In the Evening I rode into the City with Catherine called on Mr & Mrs Bentzon, and on M. and Madame Rayneval, neither of whom were at home— Also at Madame Reineke’s, and paid her for her attendance on Mrs. Adams— Heavy Rain, in the Evening.

30. Mr Plummer, Captain Lovett and Captain Leach called upon me this Morning.— Captain Lovett came to inform me that he expected to go, the day after to-morrow to Cronstadt, and the next day to sail in the Hope, for Boston— He offered to take my letters or despatches which I promised to send him in time— The French Ambassador came, according to his appointment, upon which these Gentlemen left me— The Ambassador had seen the spurious Memoir attributed in the English papers to the Duke of Cadore; but he had seen it in the Pilot of 31. July, extracted from the Courier of the preceding day, where I saw it, and he says that in the Pilot of 1. August there are some further remarks upon it.— He supposes it a devise of the British Ministry themselves; for he says that the extreme severity with which the laws of England punish forgery, is only because their Government view it as a breach of their own exclusive privilege. I told him I had not much opinion of their virtue, but I could hardly suspect them of participation or connivence, in so low and wretched a devise as this— He said they were at their wit’s end— That the king was dying, and the Prince had other favourites— Their paper was falling in value every day— Their expences, especially in Spain and Portugal increasing— Their merchants all turning to bankrupts— He had seen in the Statesman a list of Bankrupts— It took up half the paper— And so the ministers spread abroad one absurd falsehood after another merely to maintain themselves— One day it was a victory in Spain— The next it was a naval victory, and the destruction of a French fleet in the Mediterranean—the third it was the taking of Genoa— Now they were trying to coax America, and he saw they were beginning to hint that Captain Bingham’s account of the attack upon the little-Belt was not fully confirmed— Then again they were coaxing Russia, and were sending frigates and Store-ships with powder and Salt-petre which no sooner arrived than they were ordered away.— I asked him if he was sure of that—he said the Emperor himself had told him so— It was a foolish attempt at a separate negotiation, which they had tried twice before and failed; once with the frigate that brought the prisoners, and once on another occasion. (He meant the frigate that brought the Portuguese Minister[)] They were now not more successful than before—though it was said they were here in great want of gun-powder— If they wanted it, he could not conceive why they wasted it— Every third day they had some fête or manoeuvre here at Cronstadt, when they burnt as much powder as would serve for one day of battle— But at least he was sure they did not intend War with France, and therefore that they would have no separate negotiation with England— It was to be sure an aukward way of doing business if this was it— Russia had Woronzoff, and Smirnoff in England; if they wanted to negotiate it was very easy, but then they would not take such a ridiculous course as this— I told him I rejoyced to hear him say that there should be no War between this Country and France, for I had for a long time been afraid there would— He said he came here with the same apprehension— He knew that France did not intend to begin; but he heard so much before he came, and saw so much on his way, that he really feared they would begin here.— The preparations were in themselves great and menacing. five divisions ordered away from the Turkish army to Poland—(I never heard of more than four) and then the paper about Oldenburg, looked so much like a Manifesto— But that had been explained— It was merely a reservation of rights, and would be got over. There were points about which Russia was obstinate; she must shew a little flexibility and give them up— The return of the Duke of Vicence
had done much good— It was so much easier to explain and prove intentions, verbally and in person than at a distance of eight-hundred leagues— Besides, if it was thought that long residence in the Country, and personal favours received had made something of a Russian of him, when the reports of the new comer perfectly agreed with those that he carried they must be convincing. I might rely upon it therefore with the most perfect certainty that there would be no War, for any thing yet in discussion between the parties— And now, said he, we have sent eighty thousand more men into Spain, and are going to form a Camp at Boulogne, and along the Coast of the North Sea opposite to England— We shall see, if they do not think of calling their troops home to defend themselves. I said that it seemed as if there would not be a very active Campaign in Portugal— The Emperor, he replied, intended first to sweep all clear in Spain— To wear out all the Guerillas, and take Valencia and Carthagena, which would not cost so much trouble as Tarragona— Cadix would be left, and that was a strong place— Probably it would be the last Hold; but the Emperor had given great means (de grands moyens) to king Joseph, and all must before long be settled there— As to Portugal, the English would always have the position of Terres Vedras which could not be forced. Probably the War would not be much pushed there— But if the English stayed where they were, at Portalegre encamped in the marshes of Alentejo, the pestilence would do among them the work of a french army.— Besides which, there were Generals quite competent to keep the field on a day of Battle, but not qualified to plan successfully a whole Campaign— (He must have alluded to Soult)— The result of the Campaign was the only important object in War, and therein lay the great talent of the Emperor—(Napoleon.) A Battle was to him only a secondary object of consideration— It might almost be said it was unimportant— If he lost a Battle to day, he knew that in three weeks time he would be ready to win the next— He was sure of the effect of an entire Campaign—that was every thing— And that, happily (heureusement) was what they wanted here— They had not got a single General, fit to be named— Oh! if they had, with such soldiers as they have, he should be very much afraid of them— But how they went on with this War in Turkey!— This year, nothing done at all, but to return back, to where they were two years ago— The year before last Prince Bagration sends a pompous account of a victory; gets the blue ribband, and the day after is recalled because it turns out that his victory was a defeat— Last year, what did they?— lost thousands upon ten thousands of men, in storming two or three paltry fortresses, which after having got they could not hold. Why the Emperor Napoleon would not ask more than one Campaign to go to Constantinople.— As to the English, if we could but take away from them their Scotch soldiers, and their Irish Sailors, we should have cheap and easy work with the rest— The Irish are most excellent Sailors, and the Scotch are equally good for the land service; but then they have a National feeling very distinct from that of the English— They claim me as a Countryman to this day— I asked him whether he was directly descended from the celebrated John Law— No!— But from his elder brother who was my Grand-father— John Law left no children— But I am his heir, and that of the family, and am still the proprietor of the Estate of Lauriston in Scotland.— When I was in England on a mission, there was a great entertainment given in Scotland, at which they toasted me as a Scotchman— And what is more curious still, they did the same for my Son, when for having distinguished himself at the Battle of Wagram he was promoted on the field of Battle.— The General then told me how the Emperor had sent after him into Italy, where he had been employed upon a particular mission, to make him Ambassador here— He had never before been upon any but short and easy missions; always used to have it soon over, and receive nothing but testimonies of satisfaction— But now it was altogether different— I dont know how your Government does with you, said he, but from mine I can scarcely ever get so much, as a cold approbation— If you yield any thing, if you seem even to set forth what is alledged on the other side in all its strength, they seem to think you are biased, by the people where you are, and coaxed into their influence— I foresaw this, and told them so before I came away— I said I knew I should get more scoldings than compliments— However I determined to accept and here I am— It must come to what it can— He now took his leave, and about two hours afterwards I had a visit from Count Bussche the Westphalian Minister— He is of opinion that there is a separate negotiation between Russia and England— That the sending of these Store-ships was a concerted thing— And that Prince Lubomirski, whom he says he knows to be much in favour with the Emperor Alexander, was charged with a secret mission— It is certainly possible, and the suspicion is countenanced by the manner in which the Prince went from hence (see my Journal of 11. 12. 18. and 24 June last) but the reception, or rather the rejection of the Store ships upon their arrival is strong evidence, either that he was not, or that he has not executed his errand with sufficient address, or that since he went there have been changes of affairs, which have operated a new change of policy.— Count Bussche is much concerned for his eldest daughter, who he fears has a dysentery— And he is the more alarmed, because he lately quarreled with and dismissed his family physician in whose skill he had great confidence.
The Count spoke to me with feeling about the miserable fate of our poor friend Six— He is the only man whom I have heard mention it, with any profession of sensibility— Count St: Julien mentioned it to me yesterday— Neither of them believes that it was suicide— But each of them accounts for it in his own characteristic manner. St: Julien thinks it was the issue of some Night Adventure with women of the town— Bussche thinks that somebody pushed him into the Amstel, for spite against him because he was a french partizan. This is the least unlikely explanation of the three.— Mr and Mrs Bentzon paid us a visit this Evening but we could not receive them— We were all too much indisposed— I was so unwell that I could not go out the whole day, and part of it was prevented from writing— Mrs Adams was not so well as for several of the last days— Catherine who has had a cough for some time was this Evening so ill with a fever, pain in the side and sickness that she was obliged to take to her bed.

31. The Chevalier Navarro paid me a visit this morning, and told me that he should be ready to set out upon his journey next Tuesday— I gave him the letters I had prepared and told him I would bring or send him another for Mr Everett on Monday or Tuesday— He told me that Mr Plincke had at last finished the sale of his House, so that we shall be obliged to hunt up new lodgings for the Winter— Navarro was in great amazement and indignation at the Stupidity, with which the business of the Store-ships had been managed— He said that a liberal allowance for the Stupidity of Governments must always be made; but there were extremes in every thing that could not be indulged, and this was one of them— It reminded him of Oxenstiern’s advice to his son; to go and see by what creatures the world was governed— Dr: Galloway was here and prescribed for us all— He says my complaint will be nothing at all.— I wrote great part of the day— Mr Gray came out, and dined with us, the first time these three days— I sent a despatch and several letters for America by Mr Smith to Captain Lovett— Short walk on the Boulevard near our house— Visits from Count and Countess Alexander Soltikoff, General Watzdorf, and Mr Harris, while I was out. Catherine has been all day confined to her bed.

Day.— The month has been remarkable by the birth of my daughter— This Event and its consequences which have been hitherto propitious to the extent of my most sanguine hopes, has naturally produced some effect upon the ordinary course of our domestic life. Mrs Adams has been confined to her chamber, with an employment not new to her but which she had not had before since we left home—Nursing her infant. I rise more regularly than the last month, between 7 and 8 in the morning and retire to bed between 11. and midnight— My visitors are as numerous as ever; but I do not now always receive them— I have written more this month than the last—perhaps more than any month since I have been in Russia—mostly private letters— The distribution of my day remains generally the same.
